Abstract: The study of quasars and their role in the early universe, particularly during the epoch of cosmic dawn, provides critical insights into the processes of galaxy evolution and cosmic reionization. Quasars, powered by supermassive black holes (SMBHs), are among the most luminous objects in the universe and are believed to have played a significant role in shaping the intergalactic medium (IGM) during the early stages of cosmic history. This paper explores the interplay between quasars and the IGM, focusing on how the intense radiation from quasars influences the thermal and ionization state of the IGM. We present new observational data from high-redshift quasars and combine these with state-of-the-art simulations to model the feedback mechanisms that SMBHs exert on their host galaxies and the surrounding IGM. Our findings suggest that quasar activity can significantly enhance the ionization of the IGM, contributing to the overall process of cosmic reionization. Additionally, we discuss the implications of these results for understanding the growth and evolution of SMBHs and their host galaxies during the cosmic dawn. The results highlight the importance of quasars in the early universe and provide a framework for future observations and theoretical studies aimed at unraveling the complex dynamics of galaxy formation and evolution in the early cosmos.
